author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: Fed Unity Cracks as Inflation Rises and Officials Debate Future
description: Federal Reserve officials are debating what to do as price risks loom, even as its leaders and the White House say today’s surge will most likely cool.
content: Federal Reserve officials spoke with one voice throughout the pandemic downturn, promising that monetary policy would be set to full-stimulus mode until the crisis was well and truly behind America. Suddenly, they are less in sync.

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Assume Vivid Astro Focus at Tibor de Nagy, “Field of Vision” at Peter Blum and “The Poet-Engineers” at Miguel Abreu.
content: It’s been seven years since the duo known as Assume Vivid Astro Focus has had a show in New York. But this exuberant comeback effort, “Hairy What? Hairy How?” at Tibor de Nagy, is also a solo debut. Its four large semiabstract paintings and a painted table — all lavishly fringed with wool yarn and surrounded by numerous smaller unfringed pieces — are the work of the Brazilian artist Eli Sudbrack, one half of Assume Vivid Astro Focus. He formed it in New York in 2001 with Christophe Hamaide-Pierson, a French artist. These days the pair functions as much independently as together, but always under the collective’s name. This confuses, yet makes sense: Both sensibilities are rooted in the hallucinatory, multi-style, multimedia environments they concocted all over the globe for nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Altering Our Vision of Voting

content: It has long been clear to me that we are teaching the concept of voting wrong, that we are buying into an idea of false hope and optimism that is easily exploited by those who want fewer people to vote and fewer votes to be counted.

title: An NFT of the World Wide Web sells for $5.4 million.
description: The source code to an early implementation of the web created by Tim Berners-Lee was sold as an NFT by Sotheby’s. Bidders had a week to name their highest price for the source code in an auction called “This Changed Everything.”
content: NFTs, the hottest collectible that has been embraced by the founder of Twitter, the National Basketball Association and the artist who created a flying cat with a Pop-Tart body, has cast its reach back to the beginning of the digital age: the source code to an early version of World Wide Web.

title: Ethiopia Leader, Stung by World Condemnation, Denies Troops Were Defeated
description: A day after his troops withdrew from the Tigray region, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed defended the military campaign but said it was no longer bearable.
content: In his first comments since Ethiopia suddenly ended its military operation in the northern region of Tigray, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said that his army units had been ambushed and “massacred” while passing through villages, but that any claims that his military had been defeated were “a lie.”

title: Experts Debate Reducing the Supreme Court’s Power to Strike Down Laws
description: In its first public hearing with witnesses, President Biden’s reform commission largely stayed away from the idea of expanding the court.
content: Legal experts clashed on Wednesday over the wisdom of proposals to reduce the Supreme Court’s power to strike down democratically enacted laws, as President Biden’s commission on judicial branch overhauls held its first public hearing with witnesses.

content: TOKYO — Kurumi Mochizuki is the kind of skilled soccer player who can roll a ball from between her shoulder blades to the top of her head and onto her right foot, keeping it aloft for more than a dozen kicks. She makes it look so easy.

title: The N.Y.C. Elections Board Is a Disaster. This Is the Last Straw.
description: The board bungling the release of vote counts in the city’s high-stakes mayoral race is yet another humiliation.

title: Prioritizing People to Build Back the Economy
description: A robust and inclusive safety net more than pays for itself.
content: The pandemic has highlighted the harsh realities of food insecurity, lack of income and inadequate public health infrastructure. But these issues are not new, nor are they limited to one nation. With the Democrats now in control of the White House and Congress for the first time in a decade, we have the opportunity to establish programs that help people thrive long after the pandemic ends.

title: Genocide Designation for Myanmar Tests Biden’s Human Rights Policy
description: After the coup in Myanmar, President Biden is being pushed to do what the Trump administration would not: Declare atrocities against the Rohingya in 2017 as genocide.
content: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, American investigators produced a 15,000-page analysis of atrocities committed in 2017 against the Rohingya, an ethnic Muslim minority group in Myanmar. Not only do photos of Teddy and me as chubby babies, toddlers and grade-schoolers overlap seamlessly — save for my sprouting pigtails — but our temperaments, too, have much in common. We share an easy laugh, a sunny disposition and emotional sensitivity to other people, which is generally a good thing, but lately we’ve verged into mutual tantrums. Meltdowns had never been my M.O., but they have become his, and he is preternaturally gifted at igniting my fury, so we blow up together.

author: By Molly Creeden
title: Inside Betsey Johnson’s Malibu Dream House
description: The designer gives T a tour of her pretty but punk home in one of California’s most scenic trailer parks.
content: The thing about pink, Betsey Johnson will tell you, is that it contains subtleties, so you’ve got to get specific. For the facade of her house in Malibu, California’s Point Dume Club — a gated trailer park set on a bluff jutting toward the Pacific, about 200 feet below — she gave the painter a swatch that wasn’t Day-Glo pink, the color she chose for the kitchen at her vacation home in Barra de Potosí, Mexico, in the 1990s, or the bright bubble gum pink she selected for her Manhattan loft in the 1980s. Rather, she says, “the shade was close to a ballerina, with a touch of salmon.” But the precise tone, she explains, changes each day along with the light, taking on a bit of the dusty rose and orange Creamsicle of the sun as it sets. That Johnson would opt for some kind of pink, however, was never really in question. As she puts it, “When it comes down to it, what other color could my house be?”

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: To Avoid Running Injuries, Don’t Shake Up Your Routine Too Much
description: Runners who made eight or more changes to their running routines were at high risk of injury, especially if they were feeling stressed.
content: According to a new study of how runners hurt themselves during last year’s Covid-related lockdowns, to avoid injuries, runners should try not to change their running routines too much or too quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The ‘Double Closet’: Why Some Bisexual People Struggle With Mental Health
description: Even as more people identify as bisexual, persistent stigmas remain, with many not feeling fully accepted by their communities.
content: When Brooke Lindley was 13 and first came out to her family as being attracted to both boys and girls, she didn’t even know the term “bisexual.” It was 2003, and her parents responded dubiously. “Just wait ’til you get a boyfriend,” she remembered her mother saying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Vaccinated and Confused? Answers About Masks, the Delta Variant and Breakthrough Infections
description: Vaccines protect against the variants, but conflicting advice from health authorities about masks has bewildered a worried public.
content: The World Health Organization wants everybody to wear masks, but the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says vaccinated people often don’t need to wear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Yale Drama Goes Tuition-Free With $150 Million Gift From David Geffen
description: Starting in August, the drama school plans to eliminate tuition for returning and future students, removing a barrier to entry for low-income students and those worried about debt.
content: The billionaire David Geffen is giving $150 million to Yale School of Drama, allowing one of the nation’s most prestigious programs to stop charging tuition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Julia Jacobs
title: Dan Schneider Once Reigned Over Children’s TV. What Happened?
description: Nickelodeon’s longtime hitmaker separated from the company in 2018 and has been trailed by questions about his abrupt departure. Now he is talking about making a return to television.
content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — It was the biggest night of the year for children’s entertainment, and some of Nickelodeon’s top stars from across generations had gathered to honor Dan Schneider, the man who made them famous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: In Miami-Area Collapse, Echoes of 9/11 in the Grief and Rubble
description: Some who recall the early days following the World Trade Center catastrophe say the reports and images from Florida are almost too familiar.
content: Rescue workers navigating the dusty rubble moonscape. News conferences offering little encouragement. Photographs of missing loved ones assembled in a sudden memorial shrine. The anger. The grief. The faint hope ceding to sorrowful acceptance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: A Flight Attendant Drafted Her Novel on Cocktail Napkins. It Took Off.
description: T.J. Newman received a seven-figure advance for “Falling,” her debut book imagining what could happen in not-so-friendly skies.
content: T.J. Newman remembers when “Falling,” her debut suspense novel, started to take shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Richmond
title: ‘How Many Kids Are We Going to Lose?’ Four Principals Speak About the Past Year.
description: Four principals talk about how they led their teachers and students through the pandemic.
content: In the middle of March 2020, schools across America closed abruptly. It didn’t take long to notice everything that disappeared — a safe place to send children while parents worked, nutritious meals and health services for high-need students, opportunities for young people to play and socialize with one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Lydia Lunch: The War Is Never Over’ Review: A Punk Provocateur Endures
description: Beth B’s documentary tells the story of an iconic underground New York City misfit and her durable career.
content: The musician, writer and spoken-word artist Lydia Lunch is an immediately provocative figure. The name alone, right? Escaping a horrifically abusive home in Rochester, N.Y., at 16, she took one look at the burgeoning 1970s punk rock scene on Manhattan’s Bowery and was determined to both join and upend it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Remains Tight With Adams Leading in Revised Tally
description: Eric Adams kept his lead in a new tally of ranked-choice preferences, after the Board of Elections scrapped the results of an earlier count.
content: A day after New York City’s Board of Elections sowed confusion in the Democratic mayoral primary by releasing new tallies and then retracting them, it issued a new preliminary tally of votes suggesting that the race between Eric Adams, the primary night leader, and his two closest rivals had tightened significantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Before the Olympics, Mandy Bujold Wins a Big Fight
description: Bujold’s challenge of qualification criteria that relied on boxing tournaments conducted while she was pregnant or postpartum resulted in a court ruling that reopened the door to her competing in Tokyo.
content: After a monthslong battle, Mandy Bujold is one step closer to participating in this summer’s Olympic boxing tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What Do Fireworks, Baseball and Shakespeare Have in Common?
description: They are all ways to celebrate in the city on this Fourth of July weekend.
content: After a brutal wave of heat and humidity, it truly feels like summer in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: A botched preliminary tally raises concerns about the results.
description: The New York City mayor’s race entered a new chapter of uncertainty Wednesday following a vote-tallying debacle that stunned the nation and stoked concerns about whether voters will trust the ultimate results of the election.
content: The New York City mayor’s race entered a new chapter of uncertainty Wednesday following a vote-tallying debacle that stunned the nation and stoked concerns about whether voters will trust the ultimate results of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candice Frederick
title: Taylour Paige on ‘Zola,’ Grace and Being Kinder to Herself
description: For the stripper tale, the actress was mindful of the real Zola’s voice: “We’re in service of the bigger truth, the way we as Black women go through the world.”
content: By her own estimate, Taylour Paige has about 48 voices inside her, at the ready for any situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aanya Wipulasena
title: Dead Animals Wash Ashore in Sri Lanka After Ship Spills Chemicals
description: At least four whales, 20 dolphins and 176 turtles are among the dead as the nation grapples with its worst environmental disaster.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Hundreds of dead sea creatures, including whales and dolphins, have washed ashore in Sri Lanka, apparently poisoned by chemicals from a cargo ship that caught fire and sank, government officials said on Wednesday, revealing some of the toll of what is being called the country’s worst environmental disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: When Truth Melds With Fiction: Making ‘I Carry You With Me’
description: Heidi Ewing directed a film about two of her friends and their love story, both following them in real life and using actors to portray them in narrative moments.
content: Heidi Ewing knew her friends Iván García and Gerardo Zabaleta for seven years before learning the full story of their journey. Iván and Gerardo first fell in love in the 1990s in Mexico, where they had to keep their relationship a secret. They emigrated separately to the United States, with Iván crossing the border first on foot at great risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Christopher Flavelle and Zach Montague
title: Biden Pledges Money for Firefighters as a Heat Wave and Wildfires Roil the West
description: The president cautioned that the United States was years behind in developing a strategy to combat the worsening fires and their underlying causes.
content: With a record-shattering heat wave suffocating much of the Pacific Northwest and a drought-fueled wildfire season already well underway, President Biden pledged on Wednesday to keep federal firefighters on duty for a longer season, and to increase their pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A New Way to Grill
description: If you’re a fan of simple, high-heat cooking, Ali Slagle has recipes for days.
content: Good morning. Ali Slagle is in The Times this week with a smart treatise on summer grilling that argues in favor of simple, high-heat cooking followed by seasoning with abandon — a no-marinade cooking style that delivers bright flavors above the smoke and char. And without the need to marinate, it’s perfect for weeknights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Liz Day and Samantha Stark
title: Britney Spears’s Father Calls for Inquiry Into Singer’s Control Claims
description: A week after the singer’s impassioned courtroom speech, the man who has long overseen her conservatorship called for an investigation into her claims that she had been abused under it.
content: James P. Spears, the father of Britney Spears and the man who has long had a leading role in overseeing his daughter’s affairs, on Tuesday called for an investigation into the singer’s claims last week that she had been abused under her conservatorship, including being made to perform and take medication against her will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Best Way to Cook Vegetables: Low and Slow
description: Crisp vegetables are often prized, but long-cooking them into tenderness can bring out their deepest flavors.
content: Every now and then, I’ll start to tell a story before I realize it isn’t mine. Never mind that it feels like a memory of my own; it isn’t. I have to remind myself it belongs to someone else — say, a character in a novel (stealing a wallet while on a date), or my mother (visiting a rock star in the hospital after he was stabbed), or my best friend (getting sick from a poisonous mushroom in the backyard).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Opens Jan. 6 Investigation Over Republican Opposition
description: With all but two Republicans voting no, the House created a select committee, controlled by Democrats, to scrutinize the security failures and root causes that contributed to the Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted mostly along party lines on Wednesday to create a select committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, pushing ahead over near-unanimous Republican opposition with a broad inquiry controlled by Democrats into the deadliest attack on Congress in centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Ashley Wong
title: New York City Alerts Residents to Conserve Energy to Avoid Outages
description: The warnings, which included an alert sent to cellphones across the city, came as the city endured its fourth day of sweltering heat.
content: If four days of sweltering temperatures had not already distressed some New Yorkers, the emergency alert that jolted residents’ cellphones on Wednesday afternoon surely did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons and Marc Santora
title: Tribunal Convicts Former Serbian Officials of Crimes in Balkan Wars
description: It was the first time in the three decades of the tribunal’s history that top officials in the wartime Serbian government were found guilty of playing a role in atrocities in neighboring countries.
content: For the first time high-ranking officials from the 1990s wartime government in Serbia were linked to involvement in atrocities in neighboring countries, as a war-crimes tribunal in The Hague on Wednesday convicted two former Serbian officials of aiding and abetting war crimes committed in the wars that ravaged the Balkans at that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Mae West Vamped and Winked. She Also Blazed a Trail We’re Still Following.
description: New editions of her early films reveal a screenwriter with a deep interest in lives on the margins. That was just one reason the censors couldn’t abide her.
content: Mae West is fourth-billed in her film debut, the 1932 melodrama “Night After Night,” and she doesn’t appear until the 37-minute mark. But it’s an unforgettable entrance. We first hear her whiskey-soaked voice purring, from behind a wall of ogling men, “Now why don’t you guys be good and go home to your wives?” The men part like the Red Sea to reveal the blonde bombshell, poured immaculately into her gown and sparkling with jewelry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Steve Lohr
title: Lawmakers are under pressure to take on Big Tech.
description: When the nation’s antitrust laws were created more than a century ago, they were aimed at taking on industries such as Big Oil.
content: When the nation’s antitrust laws were created more than a century ago, they were aimed at taking on industries such as Big Oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Smart
title: The absentee vote count will help decide the winner of the mayoral primary.
description: The areas that cast the most absentee ballots were Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn, where Kathryn Garcia drew stronger support in the Election Day vote tally.
content: The outcome of the New York City mayor’s race will likely come down to the results of the more than 125,000 absentee ballots that still remain to be counted. According to preliminary and unofficial results released Wednesday, Eric Adams leads Kathryn Garcia by about 15,000 votes after all rounds of ranked-choice tabulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Using A.I. to Find Bias in A.I.
description: The problem of bias in artificial intelligence is facing increasing scrutiny from regulators and is a growing business for start-ups and tech stalwarts.
content: In 2018, Liz O’Sullivan and her colleagues at a prominent artificial intelligence start-up began work on a system that could automatically remove nudity and other explicit images from the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting on St. Lucia: Nestled in the Piton Mountains for $1.9 Million
description: As tourists begin to return to the Windward Island, realtors expect post-pandemic home prices to catch up with demand.
content: This 2,950-square-foot home, built in 1979 and remodeled in 2019, sits on the northern face of the Gros Piton mountain near Soufrière, a town on the west coast of St. Lucia, in the Windward Islands. The house, inside a 7,190-acre UNESCO World Heritage site, with unobstructed views of the Pitons’ twin volcanic spires rising from the eastern Caribbean Sea, was designed by John di Pol, an architect who also built the five-star, 37-room Ladera mountain resort down the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams files a lawsuit to preserve his right to challenge the election results.
description: Though experts say such legal action is standard, it comes just a day after Mr. Adams and other candidates blasted the New York City Board of Elections for accidentally counting 135,000 test ballots.
content: Eric Adams filed a lawsuit on Wednesday seeking to reserve his right to have a judge review the ballots in the Democratic primary for mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Final trial results confirm that CureVac’s mRNA vaccine is far less protective than others.
description: The German company’s vaccine had an overall efficacy of just 48 percent, but that rose to 53 percent among those between the ages of 18 and 60.
content: The German company CureVac announced on Wednesday the final results of its late-stage vaccine trial, confirming earlier data showing that its shot is far less protective than other vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: The Oldest Museum in New York Is Expanding
description: The New-York Historical Society is making way for the first L.G.B.T.Q. history and culture museum in the city.
content: The oldest museum in New York is getting an upgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Dear Leader: A Near-Perfect Letter From a Trump Sycophant, Annotated
description: Chris Kapenga, a Wisconsin Republican leader, wrote a letter to former President Trump that is a valuable master class in sucking up to the party leader.
content: Former President Donald Trump recently accused three Wisconsin Republican leaders of “working hard to cover up election corruption” as he continued pushing lies about the November presidential vote. Mr. Trump delights in turning his fire on members of his party who he feels are being insufficiently servile. Many promptly prostrate themselves; a few shrug it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Kate Taylor
title: Summer School Is Here
description: But there aren’t enough teachers to help students catch up.
content: Today: The start of summer school and a legal win for transgender students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The At Home and Away Summer Playlist
description: Your soundtrack for the season.
content: Welcome. On Monday afternoon, the temperature reached a record 117 degrees Fahrenheit in Salem, Ore. The recent heat wave in the Northwest is not “hot enough for ya?” weather or “cool off with a Popsicle” weather. It’s extreme weather — off-the-charts, as the team at The Upshot discovered when they set out to visualize the heat dome’s magnitude. If you’re somewhere excessively hot, the Well team has some advice for staying cool and safe. And The Times’s product recommendation site, Wirecutter, has recommendations for the best air conditioners and other tips for staying cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Residents who evacuated the condo were concerned for the pets they left behind.
description: A Miami-Dade Fire Rescue official said on Tuesday that his team did not find any indication of more pets still in the building.
content: Above the rubble in Surfside, Fla., on the still-standing fourth-floor balcony of the collapsed condo building, firefighters this week left food and water for a cat named Coco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Adam Westbrook
title: Are You Dreading a Return to ‘Normal’? You’re Not Alone.
description: “I don’t want to see us return to normal. I want to see us return to better.”
content: As the pandemic winds down in the United States, people are emerging from their cocoons, all fired up and ready to celebrate in a communal explosion of relief and pent-up desire. The sense of anticipation is so great that some, with lusty hope, have called the coming months “The Summer of Love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘America: The Motion Picture’ Review: In Bros We Trust
description: The American Revolution gets a frat-style sendup in this irreverent animated comedy.
content: Two nights before signing the Constitution, George Washington threw a celebratory rager where America’s founding father was said to have rung up a bar tab equivalent to $17,253. Our nation began with a hangover, a fact too factual to be included in “America: The Motion Picture” (streaming on Netflix), a raunchy, aggressively inane cartoon that flips the bird — both onscreen and thematically — to a strain of patriotism that insists that men who profited from slavery were sober-minded heroes whose vision of democracy remains flawless, bro. “That’s why we make the rules, baby!” bellows Samuel Adams (voiced by Jason Mantzoukas) after a keg stand. Here, to be a privileged white man in America is intoxicating, a truth no less fictional than watching Paul Revere win a “Fast and Furious”-inspired street race that goes “one quarter-mule at a time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Emma Goldberg
title: World Leaders Commit $40 Billion to Advancing Gender Equality
description: A quarter century after the Beijing World Conference on Women, political leaders, corporate executives and activists convened again to address gender equality. This time they brought money to the table.
content: — Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, executive director of U.N. Women
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: A Wink and a Nudge
description: Christopher Adams and Adam Aaronson have got your number.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I love when a theme snaps into place right at the very end of a puzzle with a perfect revealer (see the construction geek-out from Monday’s column). Today’s puzzle, by the constructors Christopher Adams and Adam Aaronson, demonstrates the thrill of going from being vaguely aware that something is going on to being fully aware of exactly what is going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Capri and Procida: A Tale of Two Islands
description: As Italy reopens to tourists, glamorous Capri and its quieter, grittier sister, Procida, prepare — with joy and trepidation — for an influx of visitors.
content: The aperitifs arrived as the Capri sun dipped into an orange band across the Gulf of Naples and a couple on the terrace talked about how quiet the island had become. The hotel felt empty, and its barman, in elegant suit and tie, interrupted his revelry about the prepandemic days to shoo off a sea gull deprived of its usual tourist-scrap banquet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld, Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Trump Organization and Top Executive Are Indicted in Tax Investigation
description: The former president’s family business and its chief financial officer, Allen Weisselberg, are expected to appear in court on Thursday.
content: A grand jury in Manhattan has indicted Donald J. Trump’s family business, the Trump Organization, and one of its top executives in connection with a tax investigation into fringe benefits handed out at the company, people familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karin Lipson
title: Washington Heights: The ‘Last Bastion of Affordability’ in Manhattan
description: The neighborhood, celebrated for its large Dominican community, is also known for spacious apartments, moderate rents and ample green spaces.
content: When Gabriela Madera graduated from Fordham University in 2009, she was eager to leave the family nest in Washington Heights for a place of her own in the vibrant Upper Manhattan neighborhood that she has always called home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Heat Wave, Bill Cosby, Summer Grilling: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal
title: The Board of Elections has a long history of blunders.
description: The board has been accused of nepotism, incompetence and a lack of transparency for decades.
content: When the New York City Board of Elections announced Tuesday night that it had screwed up in tallying the votes for mayor, lawmakers reacted with anger — but not much surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Donald Rumsfeld, Defense Secretary During Iraq War, Is Dead at 88
description: Mr. Rumsfeld, who served four presidents, oversaw a war that many said should never have been fought. But he said the removal of Saddam Hussein had “created a more stable and secure world.”
content: Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense for Presidents Gerald R. Ford and George W. Bush, who presided over America’s Cold War strategies in the 1970s and, in the new world of terrorism decades later, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, died on Tuesday at his home in Taos, N.M. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: A Houston doctor who was fired after a scramble to use expiring vaccine won’t be indicted.
description: Dr. Hasan Gokal found 10 people to give the remaining shots from an opened vial of vaccine. A district attorney brought the case to a grand jury.
content: A grand jury in Texas declined on Wednesday to indict a Houston doctor who was accused earlier this year of stealing 10 doses of Covid-19 vaccine — worth a total of $135 — and inoculating a few faint acquaintances and finally his wife in a late-night race in December to use the medicine before it expired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘It Taunts the Eye’: Footwork’s Fast Moves Loom Over Chicago
description: Projected onto the Merchandise Mart, “Footnotes” honors a style that’s become popular around the world but isn’t always given recognition in its hometown.
content: Footwork, the Chicago-born music-and-dance form, is famous for its speed. D.J.s deliver a tense, polyrhythmic mix of stuttering samples at the jacked-up rate of 160 beats per minute, and dancers meet the challenge with an onslaught of swivels, kicks and scissoring steps even more bewilderingly quick and intricate than the music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Trevor Bauer of the Dodgers Is Accused of Assaulting a Woman
description: The police said they were investigating the allegation against the star pitcher. Bauer denied wrongdoing.
content: Law enforcement authorities in Southern California have confirmed that they are investigating an assault allegation against Trevor Bauer, the star pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Hong Kong Philosopher Taught Life’s Meaning. Now He Visits Students in Jail.
description: Chow Po Chung pushed his students to participate in public affairs — idealism that he worries could cost them their freedom.
content: When taking a group photo with college students from mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan in 2012, Chow Po Chung, a prominent political philosopher, joked that he hoped none of them would end up in jail in 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Rogers
title: Whistling as an Art Almost Died Off. Can Molly Lewis Keep It Alive?
description: The 31-year-old has whistled at tournaments, in the studio for Dr. Dre and at her Los Angeles lounge show, Café Molly. Now she’s releasing her debut EP.
content: Molly Lewis lives at the top of a steep hill in East Los Angeles, where a group of feral peafowl roam idly around, as if they own the place. Peacocks and peahens don’t have much of a bird song — they emit a sharp “caw” that is “not cute,” Lewis said — but other birds have found themselves in conversation with the 31-year-old whistler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Shechet
title: Over 200 Million Years Ago, Nature Called. It Was Full of Beetles.
description: Fossilized feces from a dinosaur ancestor preserved an insect species not previously known to science in exquisite detail.
content: Imagine a bunch of beetles minding their own business on an algae-covered rock. All of a sudden, they get hoovered up whole into the beak of a slim, long-necked dinosaur ancestor. R.I.P. — but on the bright side, through a complex combination of luck and microbial activity, their tiny corpses become frozen in time. And over 200 million years later, scientists uncover them while rooting around in fossilized feces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: A previous agreement with Bruce Castor, Trump’s impeachment attorney, is at the heart of Cosby’s release.
description: Bruce Castor assured Bill Cosby he would not be charged in the case that was later taken up by another district attorney.
content: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court freed the actor Bill Cosby from prison based largely on a past agreement with a former Pennsylvania prosecutor best known for defending President Donald J. Trump during his February impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Apoorva Mandavilli, Shawn Hubler, Jill Cowan and Ana Facio-Krajcer
title: Are masks coming back? The Delta variant has some different officials rethinking precautions.
description: In May, federal health officials in the United States said that fully vaccinated people no longer needed to mask up, even indoors. The advice set the stage for a national reopening that continues to gain momentum.
content: In May, federal health officials in the United States said that fully vaccinated people no longer needed to mask up, even indoors. The advice set the stage for a national reopening that continues to gain momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Julia Jacobs
title: Bill Cosby Freed as Court Overturns His Sex Assault Conviction
description: The entertainer had been serving a three- to 10-year sentence in a prison outside Philadelphia.
content: Bill Cosby was released from prison Wednesday after the Pennsylvania Supreme Court overturned his 2018 conviction for sexual assault, a dramatic reversal in one of the first high-profile criminal trials of the #MeToo era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Seven Deadly Sins’ Review: Pride and Pole Dancing Behind Glass
description: This array of short plays has viewers in headphones wandering the meatpacking district for stylish, but shallow, theatrical thrills.
content: Sex and spectacle are on the menu in “Seven Deadly Sins,” a sumptuously staged, deliciously outfitted exploration of vice performed in the meatpacking district, once home to slaughterhouses and sex clubs, though now more about trendy dining and swanky shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The All-Star Game’s Lack of Style Will Be Made Up in Substance
description: Relations between M.L.B. and its players are tense, and a crass All-Star marketing ploy drew eye rolls. But in Denver, baseball should put on quite a show.
content: The venue will be different, and so will the visuals. But the All-Star Game is returning on July 13 after a one-year hiatus, giving Major League Baseball a chance to highlight all that makes it great, instead of all that drags it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Behind Biden’s Pledge to Share 80 Million Vaccine Doses: Lots of Bureaucratic Hurdles
description: A shipment to Pakistan was a recent move in a new phase of the administration’s pandemic response: a round-the-clock effort to clear regulatory and logistical hurdles to share doses with countries in need.
content: WASHINGTON — When a commercial plane carrying 2.5 million doses of Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine took off on Wednesday from Dallas for Islamabad, Pakistan, federal officials had just finished a dizzying bureaucratic back-and-forth to get them there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jack Downing, C.I.A. Chief in Cold War Capitals, Dies at 80
description: He was the agency’s only official to have served as station head in both Moscow and Beijing. Then he was drawn out of retirement in 1997 to save its espionage operations.
content: Jack Downing, the only American spymaster to run agents in both of the hottest Cold War capitals, Moscow and Beijing, and who was drawn out of retirement to help rescue the hidebound Central Intelligence Agency from a management crisis and plummeting morale, died on Sunday in Portland, Ore. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Pope Agrees to Meet With Indigenous Groups From Canada About Schools
description: Canada’s Indigenous communities have long sought a papal apology for the church’s role in a system of forced assimilation at schools were abuse and disease were widespread.
content: OTTAWA — Pope Francis will meet with Indigenous leaders later this year to discuss coming to Canada to apologize for the church’s role in operating schools that abused and forcibly assimilated generations of Indigenous children, a step toward resolving the grievances of survivors and Indigenous communities, the head of Canada’s largest Indigenous organization said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Erin Griffith
title: Robinhood is fined $70 million over misleading customers and system outages.
description: The fine was the largest ever imposed by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, which is known as FINRA.
content: Robinhood Financial, the online stock-trading app, was fined $70 million by the securities industry’s self-regulator on Wednesday for a series of failures that the agency said hurt Robinhood’s customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘White on White’ Review: Problematic Images
description: This striking, slow-burn portrait of a 19th-century Argentine archipelago considers a photographer’s involvement in the horrors of colonialism.

Baldwin is poised, attentive and beguiling as he speaks to Sylvia Chase, a correspondent for the ABC newsmagazine “20/20.” Across the segment, we see him grinning as he watches a rehearsal of his play “The Amen Corner”; we see him speaking to a group of children in Harlem; we see B-roll of him outside, catching his scarf before it’s swept away by the wind. Toward the end, the writer’s mother, siblings, nieces and nephews gather on a sofa and chairs around him. “There’s a price this republic exacts from any Black man or woman walking,” Baldwin asserts, “and that is a crime.” He reaches for the child seated next to him on the sofa. “They will not do to him,” he says, “what they failed to do to me.” We meet his unblinking gaze as his words resonate. “I was 7 years old 47 years ago,” he says, “and nothing has changed since then.”
